titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edmond Plauchut Papers
titlestmt.author: by Ève Bourbeau-Allard

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 05:59

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, photographs, drawings, and other personal papers by or relating to Edmond Plauchut. The materials document Plauchut's literary works, his travels, and his life at George Sand's Nohant estate. Writings include early poems; manuscripts for the book Autour de Nohant (Paris: Calmann Lé́vy, 1897), the study Les anciennes provinces de France: Le Berry , and his unpublished memoir Les malheurs d'un homme heureux ; a travel diary; and a humorous narrative of his adventures in the Philippines with drawings by Spanish artist Franciso Lameyer. Visual materials include caricatures of Plauchut by Maurice Sand and Francisco Lameyer, photographic portraits, and posters advertising performances at the Théâtre de Nohant, a puppet theater built by Maurice Sand.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Formerly owned by Christiane Sand. Purchased from Les Amazones on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund and the Frederick W. Hilles Fund, 2010-2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1870-1909. II. Writings, 1850-1908. III. Personal Papers and Other Material, 1861-1996.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edmond Plauchut (1824-1909) was a French journalist, writer, traveler, and close friend of novelist George Sand (1804-1876) and her son Maurice Sand (1823-1889). Following a brief journalistic career in Angoulême, Plauchut left France in 1850 to join French trade operations in Manila, Philippines. After a shipwreck derailed his initial journey, Plauchut arrived in Manila in 1851. His travels also brought him through the Middle East, British Ceylon, and coastal East Asia, as detailed in his subsequent writings. After his return to France in 1861, Plauchut frequently resided with the Sand family at their Nohant estate, where he was later buried. Plauchut knew George Sand from an epistolary exchange begun before his departure for Asia. Among the books and articles written by Plauchut are travel tales, regional histories, ethnographic studies, and the book Autour de Nohant (Paris: Calmann Lévy, 1897) on George Sand.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edmond Plauchut Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

The processing of this collection involved combining together five separate accessions of material acquired over time from the same provenance. Information included in the Description of the Papers note, as well as in file titles and descriptions, is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from a survey of the contents.
Former call number of the "Poésie" manuscript volume (in Series II): GEN MSS VOL 607.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, writings, photographs, drawings, and other personal papers by or relating to Edmond Plauchut. The materials document Plauchut's literary works, his travels, and his life at George Sand's Nohant estate. Writings include early poems; manuscripts for the book Autour de Nohant (Paris: Calmann Lé́vy, 1897), the study Les anciennes provinces de France: Le Berry , and his unpublished memoir Les malheurs d'un homme heureux ; a travel diary; and a humorous narrative of his adventures in the Philippines with drawings by Spanish artist Franciso Lameyer. Visual materials include caricatures of Plauchut by Maurice Sand and Francisco Lameyer, photographic portraits, and posters advertising performances at the Théâtre de Nohant, a puppet theater built by Maurice Sand.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Edmond Plauchut Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated material of the same provenance: the Solange Clésinger-Sand Papers (GEN MSS 755) and the Maurice Sand Papers (GEN MSS 1463), Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Correspondence, contains letters to Edmond Plauchut from members of the Sand and Plauchut families, as well as from contemporary politicians and literary figures. Letters from Plauchut's brother Colonel François-Louis Plauchut and from Henry Partet pertain to developments in the aftermath of the Franco-Prussian War of 1870-1871. Also included are letters from Edmond Plauchut to his niece Berthe Plauchut Guilhaud, Aurore Sand, and Gabrielle Sand, as well as a third-party letter from Maurice Sand to Aurore Sand. Third-party correspondence regarding Plauchut's death and the execution of his will is located in Series III, Personal Papers and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five letters pertaining to a manuscript on Swedish explorer A.E. Nordenskiöld.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Exchange of acrostic poems between Edmond Plauchut and his niece.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopies of letters from Plauchut to his niece Berthe (Berthon) held in archives in Fléac (Charente).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two telegrams signed "Plauchut".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a humorous letter signed by "Fox", Plauchut's dog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to daughter Aurore Sand (nicknamed "Lolo") featuring a caricature of Plauchut drawn in ink.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. Writings, consists of manuscript and printed texts authored by Plauchut, with a few exceptions of different or unknown authorship as noted in file titles and descriptions. Manuscripts for Plauchut's book Autour de Nohant and his memoirs Les malheurs d'un homme heureux contain holograph portions as well as printed sections previously published in other books or contemporary periodicals.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Titles devised during processing are in brackets.

did.unittitle: Les anciennes provinces de la France: Le Berry , holograph
Autour de Nohant , holograph and printed

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paginated manuscript combining annotated article clippings and holograph pages.

did.unittitle: "Études à faire sur un pays qu'on désire faire connaître", writing plan, holograph
"Histoire d'un voyage d'agrément à Cavite", manuscript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eleven-page humorous tale of Plauchut's travels in the Indian Ocean in the form of drawings and legends. Notes on the front page attribute ink drawings to Francisco Lameyer and text to the hand of Aurore Sand. Francisco Lameyer lived in the Philippines from 1854 to 1859, where he may have met Plauchut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Ballade du chasseur" composed by Maurice Sand and Sully Levy transcribed in the hand of Maurice Sand, and "Le chasseur dans les bois", possibly by Aurore or Gabrielle Sand.

did.unittitle: "Lettres de A. Barbès à George Sand", holograph
Mémoires: Les malheurs d'un homme heureux , holograph and printed

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paginated manuscript combining printed chapters with holograph corrections, and holograph chapters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes on Plauchut's daily activities and travels, including the 1850 shipwreck, the 1851 trip to Manila through Egypt and British India, his life in the Philippines until 1859, and his stays at Nohant after 1861.

did.unittitle: "Notes, extraits de 1860 à [no end date]", holograph notebook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes original poems by Plauchut dedicated to various individuals, a list of importants figures he was acquainted with, and excerpts from readings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript volume containing poems composed by Plauchut between 1845 and 1849 compiled in an unknown hand. (Former call number GEN MSS VOL 607)

did.unittitle: Les races jaunes, les célestes , advertising poster for the book
"Résumé du cours de géologie de M. Aubrée", manuscript notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unknown hand, possibly recorded for Maurice Sand who had an interest for the natural sciences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unknown hand and authorship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. Personal Papers and Other Material, contains clippings, visual materials, official documents, and other papers relating to Edmond Plauchut, the Plauchut family and their Fléac estate, and the Sand's Nohant estate. Items date from Plauchut's own lifetime to the 1990s, when the papers were owned by the Sand descendants. Contemporary visual materials comprise caricatures of Plauchut by Maurice Sand and Francisco Lameyer, photographic portraits, and posters for the Nohant puppet theater by Maurice Sand. Plauchut family documents include death notices, succession documents for Edmond Plauchut's property, and print material. A handful of documents issued by the French authorities during the Franco-Prussian War of 1870-1871 hint at Plauchut's time in Paris during the conflict and relate to the correspondence by Colonel François-Louis Plauchut and Henry Partet located in Series I.

did.unittitle: Astrological analyses of Edmond Plauchut's personality

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ink, watercolor, and pencil caricatures by Francisco Lameyer, Maurice Sand, Aurore Sand, and an unidentified creator.

scopecontent.p: Laissez-passers, military quartering order, military service order, and municipal proclamation.

scopecontent.p: History of the Plauchut family estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains 3 cartes de visite (1861, 1864, undated), 1 carte de visite with superimposed ink caricature, 6 cabinet cards, and 3 other prints.

did.unittitle: Posters for the Nohant puppet theater by Maurice Sand

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three manuscript posters for the following plays: "L'impromptu de Noël" (1869); "L'ouverture de la chasse" (1879), in which Plauchut acted as St Gaudens; and "Fouaron" (1882), which is dedicated to Plauchut and his friends.
